# Documentation for Data Sharing {.background-secondary}


## Types of documentation

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}

<br>

1. Project-level documentation
    - Project summary document

2. Data-level documentation
    - README
    - Cleaning code/Data cleaning plan

3. Variable-level documentation
    - Data dictionary OR
    - Codebook

4. Repository Metadata

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}


<br>

<br>

‚úîÔ∏è Allows your data to be correctly interpreted and used

<br>

‚úîÔ∏è Allows your work to be reproducible

<br>

‚úîÔ∏è Allows your work to be findable

:::
:::

:::{.notes}

Always share some sort of documentation along with your file

Even if you have the most pristine data file, users have no context for that file

What project this data is associated with, how data was collected and who it was collected on, any transformations done to data, what variables represent

:::


## Project-level documentation

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}

- Funding source
- Overview of study
- Setting and sample
- Project timeline
- Measures used
- Overview of study procedures
  - Recruitment, consent, data collection 
- Data preparation and processing
  - Data quality monitoring, de-identification procedures, decision rules
- Appendices
  - Copies of instruments, consort diagrams
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

![](images/project_summary.PNG){fig-align="center" width="90%"}

:::
:::

:::{.notes}

This would be where you could document your decision rules for things dropping duplicates

:::
